verb

abolish

to officially end a law, a system or an institution

noun

abortion

the deliberate ending of a pregnancy at an early stage

noun

absence

the fact of somebody being away from a place where they are usually expected to be; the occasion or period of time

when somebody is away

adjective

absent

not in a place because of illness, etc.

verb

absorb

to take in a liquid, gas or other substance from the surface or space around

adjective

abstract

based on general ideas and not on any particular real person, thing or situation

adjective

absurd

extremely silly; not logical and sensible

noun

abundance

a large quantity that is more than enough

noun

abuse

the use of something in a way that is wrong or harmful

verb

abuse

to make bad use of something, or to use so much of something that it harms your health

noun

academy

a school or college for special training

verb

accelerate

to happen faster or earlier; to make something happen faster or earlier

noun

accent

a way of pronouncing the words of a language that shows which country, area or social class a person comes

from; how well somebody pronounces a particular language

noun

acceptance

the act of accepting a gift, an invitation, an offer, etc.

adjective

accessible

that can be reached, entered, used, seen, etc.

adverb

accidentally

by chance; in a way that was not planned

verb

accommodate

to provide somebody with a room or place to sleep, live or sit

verb

accomplish

to succeed in doing or completing something

noun

accomplishment

an impressive thing that is done or achieved after a lot of work

noun

accordance

according to a rule or the way that somebody says that something should be done

a drug or another form of medicine that you take to prevent or to treat an illness; treatment involving drugs

noun

a word or phrase used to describe somebody/something else, in a way that is different from its normal use, in order

to show that the two things have the same qualities and to make the description more powerful, for example She has a heart of stone

noun

a set of methods and principles used to perform a particular activity

noun

noun

political change

one of the areas that some countries are divided into with its own local government

adjective

provincial

connected with one of the large areas that some countries are divided into, with its own local government

noun

provision

the act of supplying somebody with something that they need or want; something that is supplied

verb

provoke

to cause a particular reaction or have a particular effect

adjective

psychiatric

relating to psychiatry or to mental illness

adjective

psychological

connected with a person’s mind and the way in which it works

the attention that is given to somebody/something by newspapers, television, etc.

noun

publishing

the profession or business of preparing and printing books, magazines, CD-ROMs, etc. and selling or making

them available to the public

noun

pulse

the regular beat of the heart as it sends blood around the body, that can be felt in different places, especially on the

inside part of the wrist

noun

pump

a machine that is used to force liquid, gas or air into or out of something

verb

to make water, air, gas, etc. flow in a particular direction by using a pump or something that works like a pump

noun

punch

a hard hit made with the fist (= closed hand)

verb

to hit somebody/something hard with your fist (= closed hand)

a type of loud and aggressive rock music popular in the late 1970s and early 1980s

adverb

only; completely

noun

the act of looking for or trying to get something

noun

a game, etc. that you have to think about carefully in order to answer it or do it

query

a question, especially one asking for information or expressing a doubt about something

noun

quest

a long search for something, especially for some quality such as happiness

noun

questionnaire

a written list of questions that are answered by a number of people so that information can be collected from

the answers

noun

quota

a limited number or amount of people or things that is officially allowed

adjective

racial

happening or existing between people of different races

noun

racism

the unfair treatment of people who belong to a different race; violent behaviour towards them

adjective

racist

having the belief that some races of people are better than others or having general beliefs about other people

based only on their race

noun

racist

a person who believes that some races of people are better than others or who has general beliefs about other people

based only on their race, and may show this in violent or unfair treatment of people of other races

noun

radar

a system that uses radio waves to find the position and movement of objects, for example planes and ships, when

they cannot be seen

happening at exactly the right time

noun

timing

the act of choosing when something happens; a particular point or period of time when something happens or

is planned

noun

tissue

a piece of soft paper, used especially as a handkerchief

noun

tobacco

the dried leaves of the tobacco plant that are used for making cigarettes, smoking in a pipe, etc.

noun

tolerance

the quality of being willing to accept or tolerate somebody/something, especially opinions or behaviour that

you may not agree with, or people who are not like you

verb

tolerate

to allow somebody to do something that you do not agree with or like

noun

toll

money that you pay to use a particular road or bridge

noun

ton

a unit for measuring weight, in the UK 2 240 pounds (long ton) and in the US 2 000 pounds (short ton)

noun

tonne

a unit for measuring weight, equal to 1 000 kilograms

verb

top

to be higher than a particular amount

noun

torture

the act of causing somebody severe pain in order to punish them or make them say or do something

verb

torture

to hurt somebody physically or mentally in order to punish them or make them tell you something

verb

toss

to throw something lightly or carelessly

verb

total

to reach a particular total

noun

tournament

a sports competition involving a number of teams or players who take part in different games and must leave the

competition if they lose

noun

workforce

all the people who work for a particular company, organization, etc.

noun

workout

a period of physical exercise that you do to keep fit

noun

workplace

the office, factory, etc. where people work

noun

workshop

a period of discussion and practical work on a particular subject, in which a group of people share their knowledge

and experience

noun

worm

a long, thin creature with a soft body and no bones or legs

noun

worship

the practice of showing respect for God or a god, by saying prayers, singing with others, etc.; a ceremony for this

verb

worship

to show respect for God or a god, especially by saying prayers, singing, etc. with other people in a

religious building

adjective

worthwhile

important, pleasant, interesting, etc.; worth spending time, money or effort on

adjective

worthy

having the qualities that deserve somebody/something

noun

wrist

the joint between the hand and the arm

verb

yell

to shout loudly, for example because you are angry, excited, frightened or in pain

noun

yield

the total amount of crops, profits, etc. that are produced

noun

youngster

a young person or a child

noun

BatDauLapTrinh

A blog where wrote about lesson experience I have learned along my career path

noun

BatDauLapTrinh

A blog where wrote about lesson experience I have learned along my career path

noun

BatDauLapTrinh

A blog where wrote about lesson experience I have learned along my career path

noun

BatDauLapTrinh

A blog where wrote about lesson experience I have learned along my career path

/ˈwɜːrkfɔːrs/

Two thirds of the workforce is/are women.

The factory has a 1 000-strong workforce.

/wɪðˈdrɔːəl/

She made a withdrawal of £250 from her bank account.

/wɪðˈdrɔː/

withdraw something from something He had withdrawn all the money from their joint account.

/wɪt/

a book full of the wit and wisdom of his 30 years in pospantics

/wɜːrm/

Worms burrow down through the soil.

birds looking for worms

/ˈwɜːrkʃɑːp/

She was invited to participate in a poetry workshop on campus.

/ˈwɜːrkpleɪs/

workplace safety

These safety standards apply to all workplaces.

/ˈwɜːrkaʊt/

When I do a good workout, I feel fine.

The team had a hard workout this morning.

/ˈwɜːrði/

He felt he was not worthy of her.

a worthy champion (= one who deserved to win)

/ˌwɜːrθˈwaɪl/

worthwhile doing something It didn't seem worthwhile writing it all out again.

/ˈwɜːrʃɪp/

The Mayans built jungle pyramids to worship their gods.

/ˈwɜːrʃɪp/

The tradition of ancestor worship stretches back thousands of years.

/ˈjʌŋstər/

The camp is for youngsters aged 8 to 14.

/jiːld/

This will give a yield of 10% on your investment.

a reduction in milk yield

/jel/

yell for something He yelled for help.

yell out something He yelled out her name.

/rɪst/

He wore a copper bracelet on his wrist.

She's broken her wrist.
